newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- PRICES END SHARPLY LOWER.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- PRICES END SHARPLY LOWER.

text.p: U.S. municipal bonds ended down a point to 1-1/4 points Friday amid building concern that next week's $4.4 billion calendar will provide an unwelcome reality check for those unwilling to adjust prices to reflect this week's selloff.
While reluctant to guess what next week will bring, one trader expects muni prices to go lower still, he said.

"What happens in our market is guys don't really cut things realistically till the gun gets put to their head, and that gun generally is new issue prices," the trader said. "As new issues get priced next week, they are going to get priced to move, and it's going to crush the secondary."
As for Friday's market, the trader said while prices probably ended down about a point, thin trade made gauging levels difficult.
"A couple of trades I've seen, maybe things are off like 10 basis points just today," he said.
A municipal analyst said high-grade issues worsened by 10 basis points, while dollar bonds ended down 1-1/8 points. Activity was "very light," he said.

Dollar bonds were slow to open, but started the session quoted down 5/8 of a point. They were down a full point by noon, and down 1-1/4 by early afternoon. Some late-session improvement brought them back to down 1-1/8 by the close, he said.
In the government market, the benchmark 30-year bond was down 1-15/32 at 96-19/32 to yield 6.64 percent. In debt futures, the September municipal contract ended down 1-9/32 at 118-29/32.
The September T-bond contract ended down 1-17/32 at 112-22/32. The MOB spread was 199 ticks.
Turning to new issues, sales for next week are expected to total $4.4 billion in 126 offerings, according to Reuters Municipal Bond Information Group.
Negotiated offerings are expected to tally $3.7 billion in 56 sales, with a $660 million New York Metropoltian Transportation Authority offering through Smith Barney Inc. topping the list.
On the competitive side, 70 sales totaling $708 million are scheduled. A $141 million Delaware Transportation Authority offering on Tuesday is the largest.
An additional 13 sales totaling $46 million are on the possible calender, meaning underwriters have said they may price the issues next week depending on market conditions.
